original_data.question: A 7-year-old woman presents shortly after her birthday with red scaly plaques over both ears. Her mother reports that the patient recently received a pair of fashionable silver earrings from her older sister as a birthday present. Physical examination is only significant for erythema and tenderness over the lobules of the ears bilaterally. Her vital signs show a blood pressure of 121/73 mm Hg, heart rate of 72/min, and a respiratory rate of 21/min. Her medical history is non-significant. Of the following options, which is the mechanism of this reaction?

options.D: Type III and IV–mixed immune complex and cell-mediated hypersensitivity reactions

model_response: {'A': 'Correct. The patient experienced an immediate type I hypersensitivity reaction to the earrings. Type I reactions are IgE-mediated and occur within minutes to hours after exposure to the antigen.', 'B': 'Incorrect. Type III reactions are immune complex-mediated and do not involve IgE. They typically occur 6 to 21 days after exposure to the antigen.', 'C': 'Incorrect. Type IV reactions are cell-mediated and are usually delayed, occurring hours to days after exposure to the antigen.', 'D': 'Incorrect. Type III and IV reactions are not mixed. They are mutually exclusive. Type III reactions are immune complex-mediated and involve IgG or IgM. Type IV reactions are cell-mediated and involve T lymphocytes. Type I reactions are immediate, involving IgE. Type II reactions are antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC) and do not involve IgE or IgG/IgM. Type II reactions occur within minutes to hours after exposure to the antigen. Type V reactions are drug-induced immune hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia and do not involve IgE, IgG/IgM, or T lymphocytes. They occur days to weeks after exposure to the drug.'}</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
The day of the week on which a person was born.

The hearing and equilibrium system of the body. It consists of three parts: the EXTERNAL EAR, the MIDDLE EAR, and the INNER EAR. Sound waves are transmitted through this organ where vibration is transduced to nerve signals that pass through the ACOUSTIC NERVE to the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. The inner ear also contains the vestibular organ that maintains equilibrium by transducing signals to the VESTIBULAR NERVE.
Female parents, human or animal.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A set of two similar things considered as a unit.
The day of the week on which a person was born.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Redness of the skin produced by congestion of the capillaries. This condition may result from a variety of disease processes.
A dull achy pain.
A subdivision of a lobe.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The number of times the HEART VENTRICLES contract per unit of time, usually per minute.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

A term applied to differences, correlations, cause-and-effect relationships, etc., to indicate that they are noticeable, probably too closely correlated to be attributed to chance and therefore indicating a systematic relation: substantial, fairly large; also having consequence or import, important in effect or meaning. In statistics significant ordinarily indicates a probability of not less than 95 percent, while highly significant indicates a probability of not less than 99 percent.
Alternative choices or actions.
The means by which an effect is obtained.
A response generated by a stimulus.
